questions.text: The water vapor and pollutants tend to get trapped in the lowermost layers of the atmosphere in winters. What is the reason behind this occurrence?
questions.solution:
In winters, water vapor and pollutants get trapped in the lowermost layers of the atmosphere due to temperature inversion.

This results in the formation of smog, especially in the winter months, and this is a possible threat to human health.

Related Pearl: Air Pollution

The vertical diffusion of pollutants depends upon the temperature gradient. When there is rapid cooling of the lower atmospheric layers – which is called temperature inversion - due to little vertical diffusion, pollutants and water vapor get trapped in the lower levels of the atmosphere.

questions.text: Greenhouse gases include all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Carbon monoxide is not a greenhouse gas. 

Greenhouse gases include:

  • Water vapor
  • Carbon dioxide
  • Methane
  • Tropospheric ozone
  • Nitrous oxide
  • Chlorofluorocarbons (non-natural)

Related Pearl: Greenhouse Effect

Greenhouse gases (GHGs) or radiatively active gases (RAGs) are gases in the atmosphere that absorb some of the upward-going, long-wave radiation after they have left the Earth’s surface. They then emit the radiation in all directions, some of it back towards the Earth’s surface. This raises the earth's temperature.

In this entire process, the earth acts as an effective insulator and the overall process is known as the greenhouse effect. The greenhouse effect has a role in global warming which is the average rise in global temperature leading to change in climate patterns.

The most important natural GHGs are:

  • Water vapor
  • Carbon dioxide
  • Methane
  • Tropospheric ozone (Stratospheric ozone is not harmful)
  • Nitrous oxide

Non-natural GHGs include chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs).

International protocols on climate change:

  • Kyoto Protocol:
    • Linked to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change
    • Set internationally binding emission reduction targets for the concerned parties
    • Parties aimed to reduce GHGs by 18% from 2013-2020.
  • Paris Agreement:
    • Aims to strengthen the global response to climate change
    • Aims to maintain the global temperature rise in this century < 2°C above pre-industrial levels
    • Aims to pursue efforts to limit the temperature increase even further to 1.5°C.
    • It deals with greenhouse gas emissions mitigation, adaptation, and finance starting in the year 2020.
  • Montreal Protocol:
    • Related to the depletion of the atmospheric ozone layer, which is protective.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about global warming?

choices.text: Carbon dioxide is the major greenhouse gas
CFC increases ozone levels in the stratosphere
Kyoto Protocol called for 10% reduction in greenhouse emissions

questions.solution:
Carbon dioxide is the major greenhouse gas.

Tropospheric ozone and chlorofluorocarbons are also important greenhouse gases. Water vapor is the most abundant greenhouse gas, but the water vapor produced directly by human activity contributes very little to the amount of water vapor in the atmosphere. Hence, its emissions have not been estimated.

Greenhouse gases lead to global warming, which is the major cause of climate change. Climate change accelerates species extinction on earth.

22nd of April is observed as Earth Day. The theme for 2020 was climate action and for 2021 is to restore our earth.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an index of thermal comfort?
questions.solution:
The heat transfer coefficient is a measure of the heat transfer by convection or phase transition. It is not an index of thermal comfort.

Thermal comfort is the subjective feeling of temperature in an environment. Optimum levels of thermal comfort help to increase productivity. Indices of thermal comfort include the following:

Index Application
Air temperature Considered an inadequate indicator
Air temperature and humidity Considered an inadequate indicator

Cooling power - it measures:

  • Air temperature
  • Humidity 
  • Air movement

Measured using a kata thermometer (dry and wet)

Regarded as unreliable

Effective temperature - it measures:

  • Air temperature
  • Humidity 
  • Air movement

It ignores the effects of radiation from surrounding structures

Corrected effective temperature - it measures: 

  • Air temperature
  • Humidity 
  • Air movement
  • Mean radiant heat

It is measured using a globe thermometer
McArdle’s maximum allowable sweat rate It involves calculating the 4-hour sweat rate

questions.text: What are the instruments used to measure atmospheric pressure called?
questions.solution:
Atmospheric pressure or barometric pressure is measured using barometers.

The most commonly known barometers are Fortin’s barometer, Kew pattern station barometer, and the barograph. The Indian Meteorological Department uses the Kew pattern station barometer.

The pressure at Earth’s surface, close to sea level averages around 760 mmHg, and man is adapted to live around this.

questions.text: What sweat excretion rate in acclimatized, healthy young men is indicative of intolerable air temperature?
questions.solution:
A sweat excretion rate of > 4.5 L /4 hours in acclimatized, healthy young men is indicative of intolerable air temperature. This is known as McArdle’s maximum allowable sweat rate.

This is the maximum allowable sweat rate that is compatible with the normal physiological reaction of acclimatized, healthy young men who are exposed to heat. The predicted four-hour sweat rate (P4SR) is obtained from readings of air and mean radiant temperature and air velocity under different work intensities. Based on this value, the zone of comfort can be determined.

Zone of comfort    Predicted P4SR
Comfort zone 1 – 3 litres
Just tolerable 3 – 4.5 litres
Intolerable 4.5 + litres

questions.text: Identify the following instrument:
questions.solution:
The given image is of a Six’s thermometer.

Related Pearl: Measurement of Air Temperature

A number of thermometers that employ mercury or alcohol are used for measuring air temperature.

These thermometers are mounted on a special screen called Stevenson screen as air should have free access to their bulbs and they must be protected from radiant heat.

The instruments used to measure air temperature are:

1) Dry bulb thermometers:

These are ordinary mercury thermometers mounted on a Stevenson screen at about 1.20 to 1.80 metres above sea level

2) Wet bulb thermometers:

These are just like the dry bulb variants but the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth that is fed with water from a bottle through a wick.

3) Maximum thermometer

This is a mercury thermometer that has a very fine constriction near the neck of the bulb

4) Minimum thermometer

The liquid in this thermometer is a spirit that has a dumb-bell shaped index immersed in it

5) Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer

  • This thermometer has both mercury and alcohol
  • It measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time
  • A mercury-free variant of this thermometer is available

5) Globe thermometer:

  • It is used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
  • It has a hollow metal globe (6 inches diameter) that has matte black paint which absorbs radiant heat. A specially calibrated mercury bulb thermometer is kept inside.
  • The difference between the readings of the globe thermometer and the bulb thermometer is the measure of the radiant heat.

7) Kata thermometers:

  • It is an alcohol thermometer and consists of a wet kata and a dry kata.
  • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.
  • It was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an index of heat stress?
questions.solution:
Air velocity index is not an index of heat stress.

Heat stress is the load of heat that must be dissipated from the body if it is to remain in thermal equilibrium. Factors that affect heat stress are metabolic rate, air temperature, humidity, air movement, and radiant temperature. 

Indices for heat stress are:

  • Predicted four-hour sweat rate
  • Equatorial comfort index 
  • Heat stress index.

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely to be seen in individuals suffering from heat stress?
questions.solution:
Numbness is an effect of cold stress, not heat stress.

Effects of heat stress include:

  • Heatstroke
  • Heat hyperpyrexia
  • Heat exhaustion
  • Heat cramps 
  • Heat syncope

questions.text: What level of heat stress index correlates with severe heat strain in individuals?
questions.solution:
A heat stress index of 40–60 indicates severe heat strain. It can pose a threat to health and greatly impair work if not fit or acclimatized.

Heat stress indices include:

  • Equatorial comfort index
  • Predicted four-hour sweat rate (P4SR)
  • Heat stress index (HSI) 
HSI Thermal stress Work and effects
0 No thermal strain No work impairment
10 – 30 Moderate to mild heat strain Minimal work impairment
40 – 60 Severe heat strain Threat to health and greatly impaired work
70 – 90  Very severe heat strain Only a few who are fit and acclimatized can sustain work
100 Upper limit of heat tolerance

Only fit and acclimatized can sustain work, although with impairment

Varying degrees of heat stress occurs beyond this

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about cold stress?

choices.text: Dry-cold conditions occur at temperatures above freezing
Cold stress can cause desire to sleep
Frostbite is common at high altitudes

questions.solution:
Dry-cold conditions occur at temperatures below freezing and are common at high altitudes. It results in complications like frostbite.

Wet-cold conditions occur at temperatures above freezing. It results in complications like trench foot. Cold stress also causes hypothermia which can induce numbness, loss of sensations, muscular weakness, desire to sleep, coma, and death.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument shown below:
questions.solution:
The image shown is of a sling psychrometer. Psychrometers are used to measure humidity.

Related Pearl: Humidity

Absolute humidity is the weight of water vapor in a unit volume of air and it is expressed as g/kg of air or g/m3 of air.

Relative humidity (RH):

  • It is the ratio of the actual water vapor content to the maximum water vapor content in the air required for saturation of air at a given temperature and pressure. It is expressed as a percentage.
  • RH = Actual water vapor content x 100/ Total water vapor content
  • Very low RH can cause skin problems, irritation of the mucous membranes of the nose and throat, and precipitation of infections. 

Dew point is the temperature to which air has to be cooled to achieve saturation given the pressure and constant moisture content

Measurement of humidity:

  • Dry and wet hygrometers - most widely used instrument
  • Sling or whirling psychrometers
